text: excellent interview with  people should not be forced into one treatment model (that is 80 years old). let's always offer a broad range of effective recovery options that are clinically proven to help in recovery. many are just as easily documented.

yes and also this.-all brains learn to repeat that which brings reward. many have a predisposition to become addicted this way via 'more intense learning' . it can be difficult, but this learning can be unlearned as well. most of the damage follows the learning of the habit.
my real concern is that millions suffer in silence when good solid science-based methods exist but are largely unknown. criminal in my mind. again, well done to you, wishing you the best.
i applaud you for stopping the way you did. the method is for those that have tried and cannot. whatever method works is great to hear. alcohol and gambling disorders are similar in many ways.

dr. david sinclair did the research on alcohol addiction long ago and found one astounding answer to cure the riddle of aud. he also believed deeply in the same treatment template being used for gambling and other disorders. can we keep denying that pavlov applies to us?

the opioid crisis gives the media something to focus on while they ignore the alcohol crisis and protect their revenue stream from the alcohol industry. plus this ... does your supermarket have three aisles dedicated solely to beer, wine and now ... liquor?

love that you support "medication to reduce cravings". the best part is ... as your cravings lessen, so does the need for the medication. reaching both "normal drinking" or "full abstinence" without cravings is very doable using nalmafene or naltrexone.

this story is heartbreaking. people need a real science-based treatment that is 10 times more effective that what two guys came up with in 1939! it's 2020 ! this makes me so damn mad, people die without knowing https://youtu.be/6eghiy_s2ts the sinclair method. https://watch.amazon.com/detail?asin=b07nc3tvtr

if you are drinking too much, look into an as-needed, short-term medication like nalmafene or naltrexone. if used correctly, your intake can be reduced month by month, until you become indifferent to alcohol. once you are back in control you can make healthy choices.

naltrexone does that, if taken correctly. da is low for many, but alcohol makes that much worse over time. of the 15m people in the us (>50m claim to binge drink), tens of millions of people could be saved by dampening that overactive reward system with targeted naltrexone, imo.

agree, a full range of treatments are needed for sure. agree that some % of people have some comorbidity that must be addressed, but that is easier once the drinking behavior has been extinguished (along with the obsessive thoughts & cravings for alcohol).
and most doctors receive very little training in addiction and effective addiction treatments. thus all the aa pamphlets in the office.

all brains work the same way. they learn what gives them a feeling of reward. whether it's a bear eating honey or a human eating a cookie. alcohol gives an abnormal amount of reward for 15% of the population (dna for many). dampen the reward, the learned addiction melts away.

i am referring to a method to calm down the "reward system" of the brain (of an active drinker) so that pavlovian science can allow them to subconsciously unlearn the alcohol habit slowly, over 4-12 months. as compared to 'cold-turkey' that is.

unfortunately "choice" goes out the window very quickly for certain people (and dna has a lot to do with it). willpower alone is so difficult at this point - but effective, as-needed, short-term meds can help you get back in control !

"why do i keep thinking about drinking?" people ask. because alcohol has subconsciously rewired your brain. that's what brains do. subconsciously rewire it back to normal with a science-based method.

with naltrexone, you still get relaxed, tipsy and can still get intoxicated. but it won't get reinforced subconsciously and your journey of tapering has begun. cravings wither away over a period of months. then healthy living can more easily begin or resume.

another way to avoid a relapse that spirals back into addiction is to learn about how naltrexone can stop the spiral, reverse your cravings, destroy your drinking habit. always taking one naltrexone pill one hour before drinking. always.

the sinclair method. naltrexone is used as-needed at first (one hour before drinking, and only on drinking days), but after 4-12 months, is used far less - if ever again. your choice. your goals. the brain subconsciously unlearns the addiction just as pavlov taught us it would.
